segment.tokens: Mr. Bell tells a story of a gentleman who was riding over his grounds , once having seen a kite pounce upon some object on the ground and rise with it in his talons
a gentleman was riding over his grounds
a kite pounce upon some object on the ground
a kite rise with it in his talons
" In a few moments the kite began to show signs of great uneasiness rising rapidly in the air as quickly falling wheeling irregularly round "
whilst it was evidently trying to force some hurtful thing from it with its feet
After a short but sharp contest the kite fell suddenly to the ground not
where the gentleman was watching the proceeding
riding up to the spot " pop goes the weasel " none the worse for his aÃ«rial journey
for the weasel had eaten a hole under the wing
The weasel makes its nest in a bank in loosely-constructed stone walls
three four young ones are generally produced
seeing a mother-weasel three young playing about on a bank
The weasel is much than the stoat
you can tell it at once by its tail , which is entirely red
that of the stoat has a black tip
To-day we will go for sticklebacks ' nests
we shall have very little trouble finding a few
a calm day should always be chosen
because to find the nests of these little fish it is to have very sharp eyes to look very closely
then it is not to see objects in it
us start off then with bait-can , canvass-net , and two or three large-mouthed bottles to that small , clear , shallow pond in Mr. Jervis 's field
if we can bring home a few fish eggs
when we have caught the little fish
we put them in my aquarium
There are three species of sticklebacks found in this country the three-spined the ten-spined the fifteen-spined this last inhabits salt water
All three show great care for their little brood
The nests of the three-spined species are those most generally known
if we search carefully in the drains on the moors
we shall be finding a nest of the ten-spined fellow
Here we are at the pond , how clear it is , and how beautifully green are the few patches of star-wort in the water
how beautifully green are the few of star-wort in the water
we can all sit down so as to get our eyes as to the water as possible
never mind a few crawling ants May
do you see that little fellow crimson breast eyes like emeralds
now he darts away hides under a weed
he soon returns to the same spot
he has a nest close by
I will put my walking-stick into the water near him
Well actually the brave little fellow is not the least
he bunts his nose against the stick
he is of some danger to his nest
do you see a few small holes in the mud at the bottom of the water
No you do n't see anything
you well then give me my stick
us get the nest of the water
fanning away with his tiny fins directly over the nest
" What is he doing that for "
The quick movements of his fins bring fresh currents of water to the eggs or little fry that may be within
another fish came near the nest
he will dare to approach so near again for a long time
for those sharp spines on the under side of the soldier are like a couple of bayonets
those sharp spines on the under side of the soldier can inflict serious wounds
us leave this nest for a time
us try to find some more
that you have once seen a nest
Now you will not have much difficulty finding others
" there are a lot of the tiniest little things close to the nest
Father Stickles quite proud of his numerous family quite ready to fight for them should any enemy be enough to intrude
that sticklebacks like many other fish do not object to eat the young fry of their neighbours
if the parent there were to be removed
a hungry pack of other sticklebacks would crowd around
a hungry pack of other sticklebacks make sad havoc amongst that happy little family
having once taken a father stickleback from his nest
putting him in my collecting bottle I sat down to watch the result
Soon an invading army of other sticklebacks approached the nest for the purpose of getting at the clusters of eggs it contained
an invading army of other sticklebacks attacked
I returned the captive-parent to the water
he seemed confused the result no doubt of his confinement in the bottle
he was not coming to himself
he remembered his nest the treasures
he saw that devastating army all around it
the soldier-parent began an attack now rushing at one now another enemy
till he was left alone on the battle-field
he having thus gained single-handed a glorious victory indeed
